semantic_title: Coding Multiple Drugs and Substances - Individual vs Combination Codes
section_path: Section I > C. Chapter-Specific Coding Guidelines > 19. Injury, Poisoning, and Certain Other Consequences of External Causes > e. Adverse Effects, Poisoning, Underdosing and Toxic Effects > 4. If two or more drugs, medicinal or biological substances

content.full_text: If two or more drugs, medicinal or biological substances are taken, code each individually unless a combination code is listed in the Table of Drugs and Chemicals. If multiple unspecified drugs, medicinal or biological substances were taken, assign the appropriate code from subcategory T50.91, Poisoning by, adverse effect of and underdosing of multiple unspecified drugs, medicaments and biological substances. (Evidence: pg no: 82-83, L41-L47)
content.summary: Guidelines for coding multiple drugs or substances, specifying when to code individually versus when to use combination codes or unspecified multiple substance codes (Evidence: pg no: 82-83, L41-L47)
key_concepts: Individual coding for multiple substances (Evidence: pg no: 82, L41-L43)
Combination codes when available (Evidence: pg no: 82, L43)
T50.91 for multiple unspecified substances (Evidence: pg no: 83, L46-L47)
Table of Drugs and Chemicals reference (Evidence: pg no: 82, L43)

detailed_rules.rule_text: If two or more drugs, medicinal or biological substances are taken, code each individually unless a combination code is listed (Evidence: pg no: 82, L41-L43)
detailed_rules.explanation: When multiple substances are involved, the default approach is to assign separate codes for each substance unless the Table of Drugs and Chemicals provides a specific combination code (Evidence: pg no: 82, L41-L43)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Use combination code if listed in Table of Drugs and Chemicals (Evidence: pg no: 82, L43)
detailed_rules.explanation: When the Table of Drugs and Chemicals provides a specific combination code for multiple substances taken together, use that combination code instead of individual codes (Evidence: pg no: 82, L43)

detailed_rules.rule_text: For multiple unspecified drugs, use subcategory T50.91 (Evidence: pg no: 83, L46-L47)
detailed_rules.explanation: When multiple drugs, medicinal or biological substances were taken but the specific substances are not identified or specified, assign the appropriate code from subcategory T50.91 (Evidence: pg no: 83, L46-L47)

workflow_steps: Step 2: Check if substances are specified or unspecified
Step 3: If unspecified, use T50.91 subcategory
Step 4: If specified, check Table of Drugs for combination codes
Step 5: Use combination code if available, otherwise code individually
Step 6: Verify all codes in Tabular List

code_ranges.description: Categories for individual drug and substance coding (Evidence: pg no: 82, L41-L43)
code_ranges.requirement: Code each substance individually unless combination code available
usage_rules: Default to individual coding for multiple substances (Evidence: pg no: 82, L41-L43)
Check for combination codes in Table of Drugs (Evidence: pg no: 82, L43)

code_ranges.description: Poisoning by, adverse effect of and underdosing of multiple unspecified drugs, medicaments and biological substances (Evidence: pg no: 83, L46-L47)
code_ranges.requirement: Use when multiple substances are unspecified
usage_rules: For multiple unspecified substances only (Evidence: pg no: 83, L46-L47)
When specific substances cannot be identified (Evidence: pg no: 83, L46-L47)

specific_codes.description: Multiple unspecified drugs, medicaments and biological substances (Evidence: pg no: 83, L46-L47)
specific_codes.context: When multiple substances taken but not specified

breakdown.T50: Poisoning by, adverse effect of and underdosing of other and unspecified drugs, medicaments and biological substances
breakdown.91: Multiple unspecified drugs, medicaments and biological substances

code_patterns.description: Decision tree for multiple substance coding (Evidence: pg no: 82-83, L41-L47)
code_patterns.example: T36.0X1- + T39.1X1- (individual) vs combination code if available
code_patterns.explanation: Use individual codes unless specific combination code exists in Table of Drugs (Evidence: pg no: 82, L41-L43)

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient took overdose of both acetaminophen and ibuprofen
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Intentional overdose of acetaminophen and ibuprofen
step_by_step: Step 2: Check Table of Drugs for combination code
Step 3: If no combination code, code each individually
Step 6: Use appropriate 7th character for intent

correct_coding.rationale: Multiple specified substances coded individually unless combination code available (Evidence: pg no: 82, L41-L43)

incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Using T50.91 when substances are actually specified

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient found unconscious with multiple unknown pills
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Poisoning by multiple unidentified medications found at scene
step_by_step: Step 1: Identify that multiple substances were taken
Step 2: Determine that specific substances are unknown
Step 3: Assign code from T50.91 subcategory
Step 4: Use appropriate 7th character for intent

correct_coding.primary_code: T50.91X1- (accidental poisoning by multiple unspecified substances)
correct_coding.rationale: Multiple unspecified substances require T50.91 subcategory (Evidence: pg no: 83, L46-L47)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Should use single T50.91 code for multiple unspecified
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Using multiple individual unspecified codes instead of T50.91

examples.scenario: When combination codes are available vs individual coding

breakdown.Combination available: Use specific combination code from Table of Drugs (Evidence: pg no: 82, L43)
breakdown.No combination: Code each substance individually (Evidence: pg no: 82, L41-L43)
breakdown.Unspecified multiple: Use T50.91 subcategory (Evidence: pg no: 83, L46-L47)

examples.rationale: Coding approach depends on availability of combination codes and specificity of substances (Evidence: pg no: 82-83, L41-L47)

warnings: Do not use T50.91 when specific substances are known (Evidence: pg no: 83, L46-L47)
Check Table of Drugs for combination codes before coding individually (Evidence: pg no: 82, L43)
best_practices: Default to individual coding unless combination code exists (Evidence: pg no: 82, L41-L43)
Use T50.91 only for truly unspecified multiple substances (Evidence: pg no: 83, L46-L47)
Always verify codes in Tabular List after Table lookup
common_mistakes: Using T50.91 when substances are actually specified
Not coding all substances individually when required
tips: Combination codes take priority when available (Evidence: pg no: 82, L43)
T50.91 is for unspecified substances only (Evidence: pg no: 83, L46-L47)
